Invertible TQFTs

Jun 2, 2019

Most of this post will be heuristic arguments; we will initially only consider non-extended TQFTs (i.e., TQFTs in the sense of Atiyah), and then move on to extended TQFTs. Consider a closed -manifold (often ) with finitely many -cells . Consider a quantum system defined on : let denote the Hilbert space (we will often just consider a finite-dimensional space, and assume that are all of the saame dimension), and let be the Hamiltonian of the system. The Ising model, for instance, corresponds to the case when each is -dimensional (with basis and ). In this case, one choice for the Hamiltonian is

where and are nonzero constants, and the s are the Pauli matrices (generators of ). The first term is a spin-spin interaction term, while the second corresponds to a magnetic field. Studying he Ising model shows that there’s a symmetry breaking when is turned on.

The ground state of this system is when all sites (vertices) have the same spin, and the first excited state is when only one of the spins is different. Let us suppose for simplicity that ; then, turning on one of the spins creates an energy gap of between the ground state and the first excited state. Thanks to this property, the quantum system is said to be “gapped” (somewhat more precisely, the lowest energy eigenvalue is an isolated point of the spectrum of the Hamiltonian). Note that there is a unique ground state in this system; we distinguish the case by saying that the system is in the trivial phase. More generally, all sites are in the same state in the ground state of the trivial phase.

It is interesting to consider an equivalence relation on Hamiltonians: two Hamiltonians and are in the same gapped phase if there is a smooth deformation between and , i.e., there is a smooth path of gapped Hamiltonians for with and . Equivalently, if is a Hamiltonian acting on a state space in the trivial phase, then acting on a state space is in the same phase as acting on the state space . This suggests the following definition: if is a gapped Hamiltonian acting on the state space , then is said to be in an invertible phase if there is a Hamiltonian with state space for which acting on is in the same phase as the trivial phase. If is in an invertible phase, then it admits a unique ground state, because deforms to the trivial phase, which has a unique ground state — and, crucially, the deformation does not close the gap. In particular, for a system in an invertible phase, there is an energy gap, and the Hilbert space of ground states is one-dimensional. I think that such a system is also said to be in an SPT (symmetry-protected topological) phase.

A system in an invertible phase is short-range entangled. One definitionof this latter term (the original one) is that it is in the same gapped phase as an unentangled state (the all-up or all-down states in the Ising model). With this definition, there is a unique ground state, and in fact in this talk, this is taken to be the definition of a short-range entangled state. (A small or can only affect the ground state of the Ising model locally.) I think that Freed and Hopkins use this latter definition. I don’t fully understand the physics behind this stuff, but hopefully I will soon.

Let’s now briefly shift gears; consider a system in a gapped phase. Often, the infrared (low energy) limit (the “effective field theory”) of such a system gives rise to a TQFT. (Note that in natural units, since has units of and has units of , the low energy limit is the same as the long-distance limit.) There is a general heuristic that the low-energy limit of a gapped system is approximated by a TQFT, i.e., that there is a TQFT whose value on a closed -manifold is . For instance, Chern-Simons theory is the effective field theory of a fractional quantum Hall liquid.

Here is a heuristic argument for why the low-energy limit of a system should be described by a TQFT. Let be a closed Riemannian -manifold with metric , and let . Let , and consider , a sphere of radius around . If is a quantum field theory, then is a state space of observables around ; the space of point observables is the inverse limit of as . If are points in , then is a compact manifold which is a(n oriented, if has an orientation) cobordism between and ; therefore, defines a map . The value on operators is the -point function . If is a topological quantum field theory, then is independent of .

Now, it is a general fact that the energy-momentum tensor satisfies the property

If , then you end up with a topological field theory: the -point functions do not depend on the metric on . One way to approximate is to go to the low-energy limit.

Consider, for instance, the toric code/lattice gauge theory associated to a finite group and a character . This is a quantum system defined on every closed manifold with a triangulation (defining a CW-structure). Let denote the -skeleton of , and let be the set of -cells of . Define the space of fields to be the groupoid of -bundles over equipped with a section over (i.e., a trivialization over the zero-skeleton of ). The space of states is defined to be the (finite-dimensional) space of complex functions. For each , there is a map defined as follows: is defined to be the pair , where is the same as the section on , and is on . This defines a map . The Hamiltonian of the system is then defined as the sum , where and are nonnegative constants and

where is the holonomy of around with respect to the character : it is the evaluation of the composite of the map (induced from the classifying map of ) with on the -cycle . (The classical toric code corresponds to and being the canonical inclusion ).

What is the ground state of the toric code? If , then ; therefore, does not depend on the value of around , i.e., is a function on . If , then , so must vanish on all bundles in with nontrivial holonomy around . So at least in the -dimensional case, the space of ground states of the toric model is a purely topological invariant of . As such, we expect there to be a topological field theory whose value is this space of ground states.

Back to the main plot. If we’re interested in understanding the low energy limit of gapped systems in an invertible phase, then we should try to understand topological quantum field theories whose value on a closed -dimensional manifold (spacelike slice) is -dimensional. (In order to get something physical, we need to add more conditions, like unitarity; we’ll get to that later.) Such TQFTs are known as invertible; we’d like to understand these objects. Since the field theories under consideration might have symmetry, we will define a generalized bordism -category associated to a space with a real bundle of dimension as follows: a -morphism is a -dimensional manifold with corners with a map equipped with an isomorphism .

We’ll now consider extended TQFTs. If is a symmetric monoidal -category, then a TQFT is said to be invertible if factors through the Picard space . The data of a symmetric monoidal functor is the same as an infinite loop map , where denotes geometric realization. In this paper, Schommer-Pries shows that is the infinite loop space , where is the Thom spectrum of the virtual bundle .

Great — what about the target ? Since finding target symmetric monoidal -categories is a hard task, we should try consider some sort of “physical” universal target. What happens for low ? For the degenerate case , is just the vector space (just assign a number to a point). For , is ; for , is the category of -algebras, bimodules, and bimodule homomorphisms (as we discussed last time). Let’s denote the universal “physical” target -category by ; then, in each of these cases, the automorphism -category of the unit object is . In other words, is “”. This is literally true at the level of Picard spaces: . As such, forms an -spectrum, which we will just denote by . (Note that this isn’t the Picard space (it’s not even a space!) of any .)

What are the homotopy groups of this spectrum? Since is the homotopy of the zeroth space, which is , we find that if we impose the discrete topology on , then for , and is for . This is good: we know that an invertible field theory is an infinite loop map , i.e., a map of spectra . If we demand that the partition function determines the invertible TQFT (discussed below), then this infinite loop map should be recoverable upon taking . Taking defines a map . Since is an injective abelian group, there is an isomorphism , where is the Brown-Comenetz dualizing spectrum (they have the same -completion for every prime ); therefore, the map on lifts to a map . Consequently, we hypothesize that , i.e., that , and therefore that an (isomorphism class of an) invertible -dimensional TQFT with source is a map of spectra . Another way to say this is as follows: let denote the moduli space of invertible -dimensional TQFTs with source ; then . Since we imposed the discrete topology on , these should really be called discrete invertible TQFTs. There is a fiber sequence

Let be invertible TQFTs; then and are said to be deformation equivalent if there is an element of whose image in is the difference . In other words, a deformation of an invertible TQFT factors through , so of the moduli of deformation classes of discrete invertible -dimensional TQFTs is , the torsion subgroup of (the restriction stems from the fact that we’re looking at the image of ). Studying deformation classes of invertible TQFTs is important because this corresponds to understanding deformation classes (the equivalence relation on gapped phases we discussed earlier) of invertible (SPT, really) phases. As such, Freed and Hopkins hypothesize that a continuous invertible -dimensional extended TQFT (with symmetry ) is a map .

(I want to make an unexplained observation at this point. Let denote a Morava -theory of height with algebraically closed residue field; then, the fiber of the map agrees with the homotopy of in nonnegative degrees, and so the fiber of the map agrees with the homotopy of . Surely the appearance of in both of these places isn’t a coincidence!)

In order to test these claims against the known calculations of deformation classes of invertible phases, we need to make an appropriate choice of and . To impose some sort of geometric structure on our manifold, one often lets be a classifying space (where corresponds to the dimension of the TQFT), and be the bundle induced by a group homomorphism . One moreover requires that the image of this homomorphism contain ; the kernel of this homomorphism is the group of internal symmetries. One can “stabilize” the map : it can be shown that for every , there are compact Lie groups and maps such that is the pullback . Let denote the colimit of the maps , and let denote the map .

Let denote the associated Thom spectra , so we obtain maps of spectra . Let denote the colimit. An -dimensional invertible TQFT is said to be stable if it factors through . There is a cofiber sequence ; this can be used to show that an -dimensional invertible TQFT is stable if and only if .

It turns out that stability is related to a naturally arising physical condition, called “reflection positivity” (this is Wick-rotated unitarity; I’ll talk about in the next post). In Theorem 8.20 of their paper, Freed and Hopkins show that the space of stable continuous -dimensional TQFTs is the same as the space of continuous reflection positive -dimensional extended TQFTs. In particular, after combining with the discussion above, we obtain the main theorem of this paper: of the moduli space of deformation classes of reflection positive extended invertible -dimensional TQFTs with symmetry is .

I’ll conclude with the following. During the derivation of the identification , we demanded that the partition function determines the invertible TQFT. Can we make this explicit? Namely, given an element of , can we explicitly construct a TQFT? Let us only attempt to do this in the non-extended setting, in the case . We know in this case that is a finitely generated abelian group, say , where and are some finite integers. Choose generators of these groups, so that an arbitrary -dimensional “-manifold” is cobordant to some ; define to be the following quotient of the free -vector space with basis given by the set . Let and be two elements of corresponding to bordisms ; then, define a closed manifold as follows: compose the bordism with with . Identify and if , where is the evaluation of on . It is not hard to see that defined as above is in fact a one-dimensional -vector space. To define an unextended TQFT, we need to define a linear transformation associated to each bordism . But this is easy (it’s why the above construction was chosen): we just send the vector in corresponding to to the vector in corresponding to the composite .
